narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A broad overview of topics in NLP as well as practical implementations of neural networks and other NLP related algorithms with Python and Pytorch.
A broad survey about NLP and NLP techniques

I learned natural language processing, including both the probabilistic and deep learning approaches taken for its models, and the linguistics, grammars, and parsing techniques applied in structuring its data. I also learned how to develop NLP models in PyTorch for several of the psets, and became much more comfortable working with neural nets, taking gradients of loss functions, and deep learning in general.

This semester we covered the following topics: (1) Linguistics and word distributions, regular expressions, text normalization, edit distance. (2) Probability theory, N-gram language models. (3) Naive Bayes and sentiment classification. (5) Logistic regression. (6) Vector semantics, word embeddings, word2vec, dimensionality reduction. (7) Neural networks and deep learning (loss functions, activation functions, gradient descent, taking gradients of loss functions), neural language models. (8) Hidden Makov models, part-of-speech tagging (the Viterbi algorithm), sequence labeling, named entity recognition, the Noisy Channel model, Bayesian inference. (9) Deep learning architectures for sequence processing (RNNs, LSTMs, GRUs, Recursive Neural Nets, CNNs). (10) Encoder-decoder (seq2seq) models, attention, contextual embeddings, Transformers, self-attention, BERT. (11) Machine translation. (12) Constituency grammars, context-free grammars, constituency parsing, CKY parsing, statistical constituency parsing, probabilistic CFGs, probabilistic-CKY. (13) Dependency grammars, dependency parsing. (15) Logical representations of sentence meaning, first order predicate calculus, abstract meaning representation. (16) Word senses, WordNet, lexicons for sentiment, affect, and connotation. We also covered other applications of NLP.
Great intro course for NLP, went over general NLP concepts, statistical techniques, and modern approaches
Overarching ideas in NLP as well as software that is used for this.
I learned a lot about linguistics and computational methods for analyzing language
A survey of NLP techniques including the technical aspects, history, and the current state-of-art.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course draws on a lot of concepts from linear algebra and machine learning, but neither of these are listed as prerequisites. Additionally, at times I felt that lecture content didn't adequately prepare me for the problem sets. I'd often have to spend hours searching the Internet to gain the insights I needed, or otherwise go to lots of office hours.

It is a good introduction to NLP and the various topics although it sometimes lacks cohesion. The office hours however were not well aligned with homework due dates (being at latest on Thursday with the TAs and Friday with Drago for a Monday submission). Moreover, I thought office hours were really quite necessary for beginners. The psets were an interesting way of using what we learned practically but did not particularly build off of each other (there was a Python assignment, a Jupyter notebook, a pen-and-paper assignment, several Pytorch ones, and a short response paper).
The course covers a huge amount of area in NLP, so it is quite difficult to always keep up with lectures as they go so fast.

Strengths: This course covers natural language processing with a lot of great breadth. We covered chapters 2-15, 18, and 20 (and all 3 appendices) of the Jurafsky and Martin textbook, chapters 1-5 and 7 of the Eisenstein textbook, and covered additional topics in the slides. The problem sets were solid; all but one of them involved coding the models we were learning about in class, and they got me much more comfortable with writing neural nets in PyTorch for NLP tasks. The pen-and-paper problem set was also really useful because it got me comfortable with the mathematical side of deep learning. Drago is incredibly knowledgeable about NLP. The teaching staff, although only a few, were really helpful for problem sets both at office hours and over email; grading was very fair for the psets as well.

Weaknesses: The lectures were not recorded, which made it tough in the latter half of the semester; Drago tends to fly through topics during lecture because he aims to cover a wide breadth of NLP topics, but since I couldn't always keep up I watched a lot of other videos online and went through the Jurafsky-Martin and Eisenstein textbooks to learn it. The slides can also be somewhat overwhelming; there were about 14 slide decks of 100+ slides, but again, since Drago is covering a wide breadth of topics, it is what it is. You also have to be somewhat self-driven in this class to get the most out of it; there are only five assignments (including a take-home midterm) and the final, so keeping up with the lecture topics is largely in your hands. (The textbooks are great for this.) However, if you're interested in deep learning and NLP and push yourself to keep up with all the material, I think this class does a great job of covering NLP.

The professor and the staff were very nice and helpful, the lectures overall were interesting. One of the biggest weaknesses was that the lectures were posted online even though they were RECORDED. It might have been done to encourage attendance, however, was a big downside. Besides that, we covered too much material every lecture and the slides were very confused and ill-structured on Canvas. So it was very hard to go back to some topics and review the material before exams. Homeworks were also a bit confusing since we barely talked about actual code in class. Additionally, it would be much better to have more office hours, especially before the homework was due. For example, if the home work was due on Monday, the last office hours were on Friday in the afternoon, which means that you pretty much had to be done by Thursday night since there was barely any help during the weekend.
The lectures were clear but the problem sets were sometimes a bit confusing - office hours are good though if you need any help or clarification

Each lecture was very informative and full of content, which was a strength of the course. The psets were also well constructed and helped us learn more about language models and neural networks in depth. One weakness was that sometimes we jumped from one set of lecture slides to the next, and then back, which could be a little confusing at times.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Radev didn't post the lecture recordings to Canvas, and we weren't able to access them unless we had special circumstances to warrant it.
I liked the live lectures although I wish recordings were posted.
The office hours with the TFs/ULAs were very helpful. I do wish lectures had been recorded.

Recorded lectures were not posted and the exam was at 9am EST. It would much better if the lectures were posted and the students could take the exam synchronously like in almost all other Yale classes this year.
It was a live virtual lecture, so students could still ask questions unlike in recorded lectures
It would have been helpful if the lectures were recorded, especially because a lot of content was covered at a relatively high pace.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, with the caveat that the Pytorch work was obscure (to me), without help.

If you are interested in NLP and are self-driven enough to keep up with all of the material in this course, I highly recommend it. Drago is one of the leaders in NLP and his goal is to make you well-versed in both the theory and applications of NLP. I had heard in the past from other students that this course was not always a great option, but I disagree --- I learned a ton this semester, and even if you aren't going into NLP as a career specifically, the topics in deep learning and probability that we covered are very useful for any AI class and a career in software engineering or computer science research.
Not really, not the worst CS elective at Yale and you can learn a lot of interesting things.
Yes, if you are interested in NLP you can learn a lot about the techniques used.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: One pre-recorded lecture.
Live virtual lecture, virtual office hours.
